question: [File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-localnet/src/processors.rs] [Function: get_processor_config()] [Input validation] Can an attacker craft a malicious ProcessorName enum variant not handled by the match statement, causing the function to panic or return undefined behavior when new processor types are added to the upstream processor crate? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-localnet/src/processors.rs] [Function: get_processor_config()] [Enum exhaustiveness] Is the match statement exhaustive for all ProcessorName variants? Could adding a new processor type in the processor crate without updating this file cause runtime panics in production localnet deployments? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-localnet/src/processors.rs] [Function: get_processor_config()] [Type safety] Can type confusion occur if ProcessorName enum is modified upstream to include variants with associated data, potentially causing memory safety issues when casting to ProcessorConfig? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-localnet/src/processors.rs] [Function: get_processor_config()] [Insecure defaults] Do the Default::default() configurations for AccountTransactionsProcessor, AccountRestorationProcessor, DefaultProcessor, EventsProcessor, FungibleAssetProcessor, and UserTransactionProcessor contain secure defaults, or could they enable unauthorized access to sensitive blockchain data? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-localnet/src/processors.rs] [Function: get_processor_config()] [Configuration weakness] Can an attacker exploit insecure default values in the processor configurations to bypass authentication, rate limiting, or access controls when the localnet indexer processes transactions? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-localnet/src/processors.rs] [Function: get_processor_config()] [Resource exhaustion] Do the default configurations for ObjectsProcessor, StakeProcessor, and TokenV2Processor have unbounded query_retries or query_retry_delay_ms values that could be exploited to cause resource exhaustion and DoS against the localnet database? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-localnet/src/processors.rs] [Function: get_processor_config()] [Database connection pooling] Are the default database pool sizes in the processor configs sufficient to prevent connection exhaustion attacks when multiple processors are instantiated simultaneously in localnet? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-localnet/src/processors.rs] [Function: get_processor_config()] [Information disclosure] Do the bail! error messages for unsupported processors (ANS, GasFee, Monitoring, Parquet variants) leak sensitive information about the localnet architecture that could be used to craft targeted attacks? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-localnet/src/processors.rs] [Function: get_processor_config()] [Error handling consistency] Is the error handling consistent across all unsupported processor types? Could inconsistent error messages be used for reconnaissance to identify which processors are truly unavailable versus which are filtered for security reasons? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-localnet/src/processors.rs] [Function: get_processor_config()] [Error message timing] Can timing analysis of bail! operations reveal information about the internal state of the localnet system, enabling attackers to map available vs unavailable processor types? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-localnet/src/processors.rs] [Function: get_processor_config()] [Missing authorization] Is there any authorization check before allowing a caller to obtain processor configurations? Could an unprivileged user call this function to gain access to processor configs that should be restricted? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-localnet/src/processors.rs] [Function: get_processor_config()] [Privilege escalation] Can an attacker with access to localnet CLI abuse the get_processor_config function to instantiate processors with elevated privileges or access to protected resources? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-localnet/src/processors.rs] [Function: get_processor_config()] [Configuration tampering] Is the returned ProcessorConfig immutable? Could an attacker modify the configuration after retrieval to inject malicious parameters before the processor is instantiated? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-localnet/src/processors.rs] [Function: get_processor_config()] [Retry amplification] For ObjectsProcessor, StakeProcessor, and TokenV2Processor, are the query_retries and query_retry_delay_ms parameters properly bounded? Could Default::default() result in infinite retries or zero delays that amplify database load? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-localnet/src/processors.rs] [Function: get_processor_config()] [Retry storm] If multiple processors are started simultaneously with the same retry configuration, could they create a retry storm against the database during transient failures, causing permanent service degradation? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-localnet/src/processors.rs] [Function: get_processor_config()] [Exponential backoff] Do the query_retry_delay_ms values implement proper exponential backoff? Could linear retry delays cause cascading failures when the database is under load? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-localnet/src/processors.rs] [Function: get_processor_config()] [Integer overflow] Could the query_retries or query_retry_delay_ms parameters overflow when multiplied together in the processor implementation, causing unexpected behavior or infinite loops? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-localnet/src/processors.rs] [Function: get_processor_config()] [ObjectsProcessor security] Does the ObjectsProcessorConfig with Default::default() properly validate object ownership and permissions? Could it enable unauthorized access to Move objects owned by other accounts? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-localnet/src/processors.rs] [Function: get_processor_config()] [StakeProcessor manipulation] Does the StakeProcessorConfig with Default::default() properly validate staking operations? Could an attacker use this to manipulate validator stake amounts or rewards in the localnet? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-localnet/src/processors.rs] [Function: get_processor_config()] [TokenV2Processor vulnerability] Does the TokenV2ProcessorConfig with Default::default() enforce proper token ownership and transfer rules? Could it enable unauthorized token minting or burning? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-localnet/src/processors.rs] [Function: get_processor_config()] [FungibleAssetProcessor exploit] Does the FungibleAssetProcessor configuration properly validate fungible asset operations? Could default settings enable double-spending of fungible assets in the localnet indexer? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-localnet/src/processors.rs] [Function: get_processor_config()] [AccountTransactionsProcessor bypass] Could the default AccountTransactionsProcessor configuration enable an attacker to inject fake transaction records or modify transaction history in the indexer database? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-localnet/src/processors.rs] [Function: get_processor_config()] [EventsProcessor manipulation] Does the EventsProcessor default configuration properly validate event emissions? Could an attacker forge events to manipulate indexed state? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-localnet/src/processors.rs] [Function: get_processor_config()] [Filter bypass] Can an attacker bypass the bail! checks for unsupported processors (ANS, GasFee, Monitoring, Parquet variants) by manipulating the ProcessorName enum before it reaches this function? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-localnet/src/processors.rs] [Function: get_processor_config()] [Parquet processor bypass] Are the Parquet processors (ParquetDefaultProcessor, ParquetFungibleAssetProcessor, etc.) properly secured in production? Could an attacker find a way to enable them in localnet to export sensitive data? (Medium)
